Applications of C4B

It has been noted that a C>0.6 would be very good and highly unusual (Klaveren et al., 2018)

Search criteria

  • Cites Klaveren et al. (2018)

  • RCT (includes scores from RCTs that are used in simulation studies)

  • Reports ‘C-for-benefit’ (or words to that effect)

  • Excludes: protocols, simulation studies only, reviews

Papers that have used C4B
Ref Method Dev C4B Val C4B
Afshar et al. (2024) ML 0.63 ?
Bond et al. (2024) Cox 0.66 (Optimism corrected) 0.65, 0.68, 0.69 in different cohorts
Bouvier et al. (2024)1 Logistic 0.52
Bress et al. (2021) Cox 0.55
Buell et al. (2024) Logistic 0.55
Chen et al. (2017) ML 0.61
Winkel et al. (2024) Logistic 0.57
Hara et al. (2021) Logistic ND
Hariton et al. (2021) Light Gradient Boosting Machine 0.682
Helmink et al. (2023) Cox 0.609
Herzog et al. (2025) ML 0.55
Hoogland et al. (2023)2 Logisitic 0.5
Inoue, Athey and Tsugawa (2023) RF 0.90
Inoue et al. (2023) Causal Forest 0.87
Jakobsen et al. (2023) Causal Forest 0.59
Klaveren et al. (2018) (Stroke TPI) Logistic 0.578
Klaveren et al. (2018) (Syntax) Cox 0.59 (optimism corrected)
Lv et al. (2022) Cox 0.569-0.675
Lv et al. (2024) Competing Risk 0.696 0.675
Nuutinen et al. (2025) Logistic 0.53
Rekkas et al. (2023) (Gusto) Logistic NR (for GUSTO)
Roblin, Cournède and Michiels (2025) Cox 0.571-0.641
Saller et al. (2022) GLM Tree(?) NR
Takahashi et al. (2020) Cox NR
Trinks-Roerdink et al. (2023) Cox 0.58
Venema et al. (2021) Logistic 0.53 0.58 (Registry)
Watanabe et al. (2025) ML 0.71

In this rapid review there has been some interest in the C-for-benefit, although not always applied correctly (e.g., Hara et al. (2021)) and very rarely used in a validation set although some do explicitaly correct for optimism (Klaveren et al., 2018). There are some results that do appear to be too-good-to-be-true (Inoue et al., 2023; Inoue, Athey and Tsugawa, 2023), especially without validation in the text and RF being prone to overfitting without tuning or cross validation (Barreñada et al., 2024).

On the whole it was unusual (with the exception of Watanabe et al. (2025), Winkel et al. (2024), Herzog et al. (2025)) that both the global C and the C-for-benefit were reported.

There is some criticism of C4B (Verstraete et al., 2023) on the grounds of lack of interpretability but doens’t go much further.

The better quality work tended to have at least one of the Dutch prediction usual suspects (Steyerberg, van Klarven, van Smeden) in the author line.

How C4B has been applied is frequently unclear, e.g., Lv et al. (2022) has very similar C-for-risk and C-for-benefit scores which hasn’t been seen in other studies.

In the original method you have the ternary outcome of {-1, 0, 1} denoting {harm, no difference, benefit} however with a survival model you would end up with {harm, unknown due to censoring, benefit} like in the implementation of Harrell’s C (Harrell, 2015) where when comparing pairs of observations those of the form of A being censored prior to B having an event would not be included in the calculation.3 The issue that one has is that pairs could be chosen but not have a valid status. Essentially the status of all pairs must have an ordered output. One option that may have been applied is implementing an arbitrary cut-off point and dichotomising. Efthimiou et al. (2025) extended the original method to survival models where unknown is interpreted as no difference.

What is missing?

C4B outside of logistic

There are relatively few CPMs that examine neither a binary nor survival outcome. So it is not massively surprising that there is little work on models not in these forms.

Matching approaches

In more recent papers, there is a brief mention of using Mahalanobis distance, and only since Hoogland et al. (2024) and mentioned in Maas et al. (2023). I think there are better approaches. There is also a need to report what the matching technique is.

What is a good C4B?

Klaveren et al. (2018) stated that 0.6 was a good score and that would be consistent with the results from the studies so far. I think there is a need for simulation with various types of model and variance to see how global discrimination correlates with C4B.

Validation

There were very few studies that explicitly state that the discrimination is optimism corrected/internal-external validated of validated in an independent cohort.

References

Afshar, M. et al. (2024) “Machine learningdriven analysis of individualized treatment effects comparing buprenorphine and naltrexone in opioid use disorder relapse prevention,” Journal of Addiction Medicine, 18(5), p. 511. Available at: https://doi.org/10.1097/ADM.0000000000001313.
